Key Arguments: The bill infringes on freedom of speech by compelling tech companies to censor content that could be construed as harmful.
The bill lacks clear standards and relies on subjective definitions of misinformation and disinformation.
The government is positioned as the sole arbiter of truth, which could lead to manipulation of information.
Historical examples show that unpopular ideas can later be proven true, indicating the fallibility of current 'truths'.
The bill empowers an unelected body (ACMA) to determine misinformation, which could lead to abuse of power.
The legislation promotes ideological conformity and suppresses dissenting voices.
There is a lack of clarity, accountability, and safeguards against misuse of censorship powers.
The exclusion of government-authorized content from censorship is hypocritical and inconsistent.
Notable Quotes: This bill tramples on freedom of speech by compelling big tech to silence discussion which, even unintentionally, causes 'harm'.
The Bill presumes that the government is the source of, and definer of truth, and empowers them to control and manipulate the flow of information.
The Bill effectively compels tech companies to become tools of government censorship, stifling free speech and undermining the open exchange of ideas.
We urge the government to withdraw this Bill and uphold the fundamental rights of every Australian citizen as stated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
